reviewText: Metro 2033 more than makes up for its linear gameplay by making the world extremely rich and detailed. The sounds and sights of the tunnels and the post apocalyptic surface world are amazingly interesting and beautiful. Stepping out of the metro and into the open world for the first time is stunning. Also, the survival horror feeling is strong, light mechanics and the gas mask fogging up on you adds a very realistic edge.

reviewText:
In this simulator from Rail Corporation NSW you play as Artyom, a hapless commuter on Sydney's metropolitan train network, as he undertakes an eight day journey in his attempt to travel from his home near Macarthur station to the distant destination of Central to not only get to work on time, but to search for answers in mankind's darkest hour of public transport.

RailCorp has fashioned an amazingly realistic depiction of the city's railways with a number of hurdles that really emphasise Artyom's struggle to reach his destination, including peak hour travel, passive-aggressive passengers, psychotic bogans, vandals and vagrants. Dotting the brightly-lit and sometimes vandalised environment are allies in the form of CityRail employees who are normally helpful and competent with only the occasional buggy transit officer becoming inexplicably hostile detracting from the experience.

I give this 9 avoidable delays out of 10.

reviewText:
Metro 2033 is a story-driven FPS game developed by a Ukrainian team and is based on the book with the same title written by Dmitry Glukhovsky. Now, when I say story-driven it means the game does not offer multiplayer - its sequel, Metro Last Light, followed the same concept. This is an FPS game focusing on only the single player experience. To be honest this is quite rare for an FPS nowadays and this is why this game I considered a nice change considering the usual formula.

In the near future due to World War III Moscow is devastated by atomic bombs. The issue is not really with the destruction caused by the missiles but with the radiation that requires citizens to flee from the city. As the best solution a lot of people go into the depths of the Moscow underground and the game takes place a couple of decades later when there is already an established society down there. Supplies and resources are scarce and not only are the survivors threatened by the mutants that were born as a result of the catastrophe but also by the evil of men which resurfaces as some decide to apply some good old ideologies that were meant to remain vanished. Factions are born and our protagonist, Artyom, finds himself between these two who are waging war against one another. And while the mutant animals also pose a threat there is a mysterious new race only referred to as the Dark Ones who occasionally appear to decimate each side.

So, with Artyom you fight all these people in the subways. This gives the gameplay an interesting touch - sometimes the enemies just consist of mutants. You go through dark corridors with creepy atmosphere and you see holes everywhere and you're wondering when and how many monsters will jump at you all at once. Other times its all about the factions - you fight against people and these levels let you take them head-on or follow a more stealthy approach.

You have a knife at your disposal so that you can take down the enemies silently and from a safe distance. Your foes, however, are not stupid - they employ a handful of traps and you should deactivate these otherwise you are in for a not very nice surprise. Later on you will do all this on the surface - you leave the underground world only to find yourself in a poisonous world. You have a gas mask and limited oxygen supply and you quickly need to reach your objective before time runs out.

The 4A Engine does a wonderful job. Every place, every corridor, every enemy looks very detailed. The game is mostly dark so the lighting you have here is excellent. You can shoot light bulbs to make the place darker and be able to approach your foes for a takedown. While the game looks stunningly good you cannot really be positive when it comes to its optimisation. Even with today's PC hardware the game can produce a lower than 60 FPS. It is an issue only because the game's sequel uses the same engine but looks and runs better. Also, the game does not allow you to change the graphics settings one by one but just provides you with a preset option. More freedom in this would have provided players with more room for tweaking and eventually a smoother gameplay experience.

The game can, at times, be very challenging which is good for FPS veterans. An extra challenge comes in the form of the so-called Ranger Mode. This mode tries to make the game more realistic - bullets can kill Artyom much easier but the same goes for the enemies. Also, Heads-Up Display is completely disabled. Obviously, this difficulty means you should further focus on the stealth approach as when human enemies are around running and gunning is not an option.

The game has two endings. One is considered bad while the other is the good way to finish the game. The latter requires you to obtain a lot of moral points. These can be obtained in various ways - you talk to people or you simply listen to all conversations, you give bullets to beggars (bullets are the in-game currency), you do not accept rewards, you play musical instruments found throughout the game etc. The downside in all this is that the game never really explains the mechanics here. You can only guess what is going on as at times the screen flashes brightly to indicate you have just gained a moral point. Also, there are no score or statistics screen telling you how many points you have obtained and how many remain to be found. I was not able to complete this so I always got the bad ending (which is considered canonical when it comes to the game's sequel).

I liked Metro. I found it a unique experience with its dark, creepy tunnels and dead city and hordes of mutants. I liked to participate in Artyom's desperate journey to find his station help from the people living in Polis, the greatest station of all. The people who belong to the council and who can make decisions that can change the lives of the denizens of Metro. This was a long journey and I enjoyed every minute of it.

reviewText:
게임을 끝마친 후 소설을 통해 좀더 자세한 내용을 알고 싶은 마음이 강하게 들었다.
그만큼 이 게임은 분위기를 무척이나 잘 살렸고 그에 따른 몰입도가 상당하다.
또한 단순한 형태로 끝나는 다른 FPS 게임들과는 다르게 상당한 집중을 요하는 잠입 요소도 갖추고 있다.
그냥 무턱대고 쏘고 넘어가는 형식으로는 이 게임을 제대로 플레이할 수가 없다.
이런 점도 Metro 2033의 또다른 재미이자 장점이라 생각한다.

큰 장점을 갖고있는 만큼 개인적으로 단점도 너무나 크게 느껴졌다.
일단 동료들과 같이 진행하는 부분에서 아군의 인공지능이 너무나 형편없다.
게임의 난이도를 쉽게 설정해서 진행한다고 해도 동료 하나때문에 몇 번 이상을 반복해야하는 경우가 생긴다.

출시한지 꽤 지난 게임임에도 불구하고 치명적인 버그 또한 존재한다.
무조건 도망을 가야하는 부분에서 달리기가 갑자기 안된다거나, 몸을 숙여서 들어가야하는 공간에서 숙여도 진행을 할 수 없다거나,
총기 장전이 안된다거나, 캐릭터 끼임 현상이 발생한다거나...

너무 큰 단점때문에 맘같아선 추천하지 않는 쪽으로 선택을 하려다 단순히 몰입감 하나 때문에 맘을 바꾼다.

One of the possibly best single player game/game series unbeatable unless your compare it to it's successor but it is an amazing game hands down where choices actually matter and effect your ending.
Graphics-Great 9/10

Voice acting-Good 8/10
Depth-Excellent 10/10
Characters-Amazing 10/10
Customization-Great 9/10
Weapons-Great 9/10
Atmosphere-Amazing 10/10
Storyline-Amazing 10/10

reviewText:
I just beat this game for the first time and had a blast. Here's what I think:

Story: 8.5/10
I haven't played Last Light yet, but the story in this game is fairly engrossing. It's post-apocalyptic Russia where everyone takes refuge in the subways and monsters have appeared on the irradiated surface. They've been making their way into the subway and now threaten the human survivors there. Also, nazis! Every single character is completely forgettable except for  Bourbon, who you learn about through interactions with other NPCs as you travel together but is otherwise totally unimportant to the story.

The bloodthirsty and shortsighted quality of the nuclear warfare that destroyed the planet is a recurring theme in the game, which I was pleased to see. You can get two different endings based off of morality points" that are collected throughout the game in ways that might surprise you (and sometimes definitely don't). The idea that destruction and death are sinful and that there is an ultimate but not obvious price to paid for one's bloodlust is tied into a lot of the sequences and decisions in the game and it's really cool to see a story that explores them in a nuanced and careful fashion
date:
rather than shoving it down your throat. There are some dream-like sequences that are really cool to play through as well.

Aesthetics: 9/10
This game is absolutely gorgeous. And not just because the graphics are good; many objects and models are incredibly detailed and some level of thought to the overall atmosphere was given to every single point in the game. The enemies are really
hoursPlayed: especially the ones near the last third of the game. The way you track your filters
votesHelpful: and other little interactions with the wold are all very detailed and atmosphere-appropriate. I'm not a huge fan of post-apocalyptic grunge-scapes but the way they presented these subways and the above-ground areas are really just stunning
votesTotal: and I'd recommend you see for yourself.\n\nThe sound is good
votesFunny: I didn't notice anything really stellar about it but it wasn't bad either. Some sound effects seemed a little low-quality or just bad
commentsCount: but the stereo image was very nice overall.\n\nit would be a 10/10
column16: but there are plenty of glitches that kill the immersion - sometimes looking at your watch makes the whole screen blurry instead of just the background
column17: dead monster corpses look more alive than living monsters most of the time
column18: somtimes monsters sound like they're right behind you when really they're behind a wall
column19:
sometimes (with 2-handed guns) your extra hand bobs out of sync with the gun and it looks really dumb. There's a bunch of stuff like that but it didn't bother me enough to keep me from enjoying all the things about the game that are great.


Gameplay: 7/10
Unfortunately
column20: gameplay is where this game really falls short. Shooting mechanics feel blimpy and unresponsive
column21: guns are in no way balanced
column22: scripted sequences depend on you to be standing in or beyond a certain point and can make for some really stupid moments
column23: and some sequences seem a little poorly planned in general.\n\nAlso
column24: the amoebas. I don't know how or why
column25: but they are enemies you will only encounter in a single spot right near the end of the game for what appears to be no particular reason
column26: and they are so insanely frustrating that it just doesn't fit with the rest of the game. You're stuck with an AI npc who can take a lot of damage but isn't invincible and does nothing to avoid being hit. The blobs come out of pink holes in the ground that can be destroyed by gunfire
column27: which makes absolutely no sense. I had to find that out by looking online. The blobs are numerous and it only takes one or two to kill you
column28: depending on the difficulty. But even if you kill them
column29: they still leave behind harmful residue
column30: just not as much. You need to stay far away from your companion in order to survive because he can and will take ten times more damage than you can possibly handle
column31: but at a later point in the game you will be insta-killed by monsters as a punishment for getting too far away. Really
column33: so dumb. It stands out sorely as a low point in this game but luckily only lasts very briefly.\n\nAlso the AI is atrocious. Stealth is almost impossible because hit boxes are also atrocious
column34: and as I'm sure you've heard if it takes two throwing knives to kill someone instead of one
column35: the whole level immediately begins firing at you even if your victim never made a peep. There are also portions where stealth is impossible

Overall I give this game 8 out of 10 its recomended.

voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you enjoy Thriller and suspence Movies then this is a game you will enjoy.

Story: 9.5/10
This game is based off a Russian novel set in the distant future, hence the 2033, in the subway tunnels of a ravaged world, hence the Metro (other countrys call their subways the Metro). It is well writen and keeps you wondering what is going to happen next. I have only gone through this game once on Steam but Ihave played through it more then once and it is almost a requirement to go through it more than once to get the full picture of this world. The only down side is that it is about a 10-3 hour story depending on your skill a puzzle solving, shooting, and if you are blazing through the game. It is not reccomneded to rush through as yuo will miss out on what the game has to offer.

Visuals: 9/10
You are underground. Humanity is rather primitive. ITS DARK, but it all feels like it should be that way not like this is some sort of cheap shot to get you scared. The other details of the game are well placed and rather clean.

Sound: 10/10
The sound completely sets the mood and it is what makes you keep looking behind you in the tunnels. Its is clkear, definate, and constantly keeping you on your toes. This is the most well done part of this game.

Game play: 8.75/10

This game is a FPS. If you have played a FPS before you will be very familure with how to play. The wepons are makeshift versons of what you would expect to see today. The stealth element of this game is done well. It gives you the option to go steath or rambo it thats not your style. Linar, it is in subway tunnels so it feels like it is supposed to be that way insted of leaving you wondering why you cant go there.

Overall, This game shines in a imersive story that can be on the short side so if you can find this game on the $15 or less side it shoudl be a instant buy.

reviewText: I have to say for a game that has been talked bad about I can't see what there seeing. Yes AI are dumb at times and don't match up to par of what is being said but still that is nothing giving away from the gameplay. Presentation is outstanding and graphics are really eye dropping for how old it is but my old problem with the game is the blood it feels... Too watery and run down and just stands out might be because i'm running AMD but it doesn't matter. Gameplay is enjoyable at times when it saves you not that far after you where killed I had to change the game difficulty to EASY and still was being murder around every corner. Good news sometimes I wasn't that far back from what I did before I died and other times it varied so I give it 50/50 on being good saving. No there is no manual saving before you ask. Story sets up alright goes looking for someone his friend told him to go look for and progress into a go do this i'll get you here type story for most of it but it was enjoyable considering the environment and atmosphere in the metro tunnels and above ground kept it refreshing while mowing down some mutants. All in all game is pretty good the only thing sets apart are it god like eniemes and the blood being a little too run down it gets a 8.5/10 soild but just little things that do matter.

reviewText:
The game is set in Moscow's metro in a post apocalyptic future, where human are forced to live like animals.You play as Artyom, a young boy who through a thousands adventures save his native station and the entire Metro. He'll face mutants that through devastated surface penetrate into underground, and humans who left humanity to embrace the beast within.

The game gives to the player the sensation of claustrophobia and desolation of metro, showing the hard condition of people who inhabit it.

As you can see I appreciated the setting, and gameplay too. I found only a few defects, like the engine which isn't scalable and is heavy, and the stealth sessions, that ins't cured like all the other parts of the games.

8/10
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
ARTYUM!

First off, The gunplay and some of the actual guns flat out suck in this game, I don't care how drunk Artyum is or how you excuse it- the mechanics don't ever feel right. But the experience is well worth the hiccups.

Like the Witcher, it's based on a novel, so it arlready has inherent depth.  It'll appeal to a majority of sci-fi and horror fans alike. I won't lie, this game is genuinely scary, with a lot of really bizarre and out-of-this world cut scenes. Don't skip them.

The graphics are still freakin' good by today's standards, and the sound and art direciton are top of their class in my opinion.

Keep in mind, ammo is limited and enemies are unforgiving if you let them get close or you inevitably miss with Artyum's shaky drunken hands.

There's a running joke around his part of the Metro that he's a dead-eye."   Uh-huh.  >.> These womp rats will be standing right in front of you
date: and both shells from the trusty double barrel will inexplicably miss.  Luckily

reviewText:
Metro 2033 has some of the best atmosphere I've ever seen in a game. It's dark and moody which adds a certain tension to the game. It also looks great in motion, apart from the faces. The faces could use some extra work, but thankfully most of the NPC's you meet have helmets on so it keeps you (mostly) immersed.

The fact that you can use ammo for your weapons or as a way to trade for stuff is a great idea, and gives the player a sense of freedom. That's all the freedom there is though; the game is quite linear. I honestly expected the game to be a bit more open. After all: you're walking around in the underground, you're frequently being shown a map of this very underground, but unfortunately, the game keeps you from exploring any of the tunnels that are not part of the story.

There are also a few stealth levels. These levels don't work as well as you would expect. I had to restart quite a few times. The game's just not build for this sort of gameplay. Then again, it's only a few levels so it's not a big deal. But still worth mentioning.

Metro 2033 was a pleasant surprise for me. I'm glad I finally decided to finish it, after a 2 year long backlog delay ;)
(Also, the game's framerate is all over the place. I had to change it to DX9 in order for it to give me a stable framerate. So in case you're experiencing the same thing...)

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText: If Call of Duty is a boisterous, loud, dumb shooter that prides itself on Western militarism and mindlessly shooting at the terrorists THREATENING OUR FREEDUMS, Metro 2033 is an incredibly depressing, somewhat malformed, subtle, intricate take on post-apocalyptic Russia that focuses on resource scarcity and what being cooped up in an underground bomb shelter for 20 years does to humanity. Like the STALKER games, it does a lot of things wrong (the ♥♥♥♥ing bad checkpoint system), but the flaws add to its depth and charm. It is completely linear, but it is certainly leagues beyond the ♥♥♥♥ that Cal of Duty and all of its other 'me-me-me' competitors are doing right now.

reviewText:
This game is amazing! The sounds, the graphics and the gameplay is super cool and creepy. When you walk around in a station you can hear all kind of storys. The tank that was dugd into the ground, the submarines that stayed at their posts or attacked when the first bombs fell to take revenge for their families. There is a lot of exploration for a FPS, but tha game is not that long. 12 - 15 hours depending on how much you explore or what difficulty you have. Wish leads to the ranger mode where you have no crosshair and die much more easily! This is a game that you can, with no problem, play multiple times. The endings are really satisfying and they are not in your face. Most games would put two giant signs, one red and one blue, but in metro you actually have to think and react fast. No signs and no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It felt like MY choise.

Over all an amazing experience with nothing but fun and creep. 9 out of 10!

I also recommend reading the books!

reviewText:
Scariest game I've played on Steam and probably in my top three ever. Creepy noises and a desolate setting filled with mutated monsters that want to eradicate/eat the last of the human race strangely adds to engaging me even more. Combat and adventures are hard and only the most hardcore types should start their first time around on anything but easy. Ammo is limited so you have to scrounge or get used to fighting with your knife which only makes it scarier. Monster noises are the scariest especially when you've got ten bullets left in your pistol and no healing packs. Ask me how I know that. Heh.

The game is sometimes linear but for those with limited time you can finish this game in ten to fifteen hours tops. Based on a novel of a similar name.

reviewText: If you enjoyed Fallout 3, you need to buy this game. Other than Fallout 3 I have yet to play a game with atmosphere this palpable and real, or characters that seem so believable. Combat is pretty good as well, but feels a bit Modern Warfare-ish (i.e. spray-and-pray with a bit of sneak). The reason that I emphatically recommend this game to Fallout 3 fans is because Metro 2033 differs from Fallout by offering a more focused narration. Yet Metro 2033 compares to Fallout 3 by existing in a semi-plausible, post apocalyptic world where individual survival is not only paramount, it also acts as a force in the plot. I have played only a few other games that provide this much tension and atmosphere. Two thumbs up, if you can handle it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Metro 2033 is the post-apocalyptic, Russian Half-Life. You wander round in the squalor of the crowded metro stations, crawl through the filth of the tunnels, and try to survive on the irradiated surface in dust-choked Moscow. The currency of the game are military-grade bullets, which are also extremely effective at killing things! You can trade your military bullets for cheaper bullets, or you can metaphorically shoot your money away. And you need to keep a supply of gas mask filters outside of the metro stations or else you'll choke to death. It's very immersive, beautiful (in it's own ways), and plays as well as more popular western games.

reviewText: Great game with good atmosphere, stunning visuals and very solid gameplay. It is one hell of a thrilling ride and who would have thought how many different locations there are to explore in a metro?! From start to finish Metro 2033 is very well paced with some great shooting sections, some mostly optional stealth segments and very few, yet nonetheless great quick-time events. Even when you think that you have progressed far enough into the game to not be suprised anymore, the game will do so. The same goes for the weapons.\nOverall Metro 2033 is a great experience that nobody should miss!!

reviewText: Call of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. The story was enjoyable, with some interesting characters, like Bourbon, Khan and Ulman; however, I didn't like the endings: they make no sense, and I don't think Artyom would choose either one, not to mention following Miller's insane plan without saying a word. His muteness throughout the game is beyond my comprehension, he should have said something at least to the kid he takes with him at one point. The setting is certainly very atmospheric with the run-down metro stations, the half-collapsed tunnels and that AK-74 ammo is the money, but, unfortunately, it makes very little sense. There is no way these monsters could have evolved in just 20 years (it's at most their 6th generation), I don't know what they could eat in a permanent winter, I can't believe the survivors could find enough uncontaminated water, I wonder where they get electricity from, and AFAIK .44 caliber revolvers are not used in Russia.\n\nThe game mechanics are also a mixed bag. I really liked the crudeness of the homebrew weapons, the intense stealth missions, and it's an interesting twist that the game gives achievements for not killing the nazis. There are some odd features, though: the throwing knife kills silently, but the normal knife doesn't, Artyom has to change filters in the gasmask every 5 minutes, yet there are people who practically live on the surface, and filters can only be bought in the first two stations. The checkpoint system without the ability to save manually adds tension to the gameplay, but it also discourages experimentation, especially on the surface, where filter time is very limited.

reviewText: Metro 2033 puts you in the shoes of the young Artjom and is oriented alongside the book series of the same name. The devs of 4A Games do a far over the top job when it comes to atmosphere. As many of you might know, the setting is around the complex post-apocalyptic metro system of Moscow with a few surface missions ( streets of Moscow, library, etc ) and the game manages to catch you in its horrendous monster and bandit" infested tunnels
date: holes and streets of Moscow.\nThe whole amtospheric aspect is underlined by lovely details on every corner of the game: The artistic style and how the Metro is designed are just amazingly breathtaking. The (wide variety of) enemies  (with their specific weaknesses and skills) seem realistic and you are mostly able to choose the stealth or guns blazing approach when it comes to humans. Weapons feel great and even though you only can carry three firearms at a time
recommended: there is a choice in weaponry and even customization. Whatever tingles your senses - be it surpressor

reviewText:
I bought this game based on the recommendation of a friend and I wasn't disappointed.
This is one of the best first person shooters on the market.
It's dark, creepy and genuinely feels like a post apocalyptic world where even the open air can kill you.
The weapons feel authentic to the world in which they occupy and the mutants are grotesque and deadly!
The only downside to this game is it's quite resource heavy so you will need a fairly powerful GPU to handle it.
Highly recommended.

reviewText: If you like STALKER, you'll like Metro 2033. Same ideas are brought together in this much more linear, first person shooter experience. There are also a few quick time events that some people find annoying, but the engine is superbly done. Lots of great ideas are pulled from STALKER and perfected in Metro.

reviewText:
Um estonteante game que felizmente teve uma boa adptação baseado
em um romance de Dmitriy Gluskhovskiy.

Fantástica a aventura que esse game pode nós oferecer em um ambiente
pós-apocalíptico visualmente bem trabalhado com trilha sonora de qualidade,
comandos e jogabilidade agradável.

O protagonista Artyom parece do tipo de pessoa que fala pouco e age mais,
ele se mantém silencioso o jogo todo.

A radiação, devido a uma guerra nuclear mundial, trouxe ao mundo uma nova espécie
de vida, essa espécie é comentada durante o jogo por alguns inimigos e
sobreviventes, que são....( não vou dar spoiler).

A luta pela sobrevivência no subterrâneo entre inimigos mutantes,confronto
entre facções de nazistas e comunistas e os problemas internos do metro, onde
você poderá ajudar ou não pessoas necessitadas, isso entre outros
elementos faz com que esse game tenha um trama super envolvente.

Divertido, um fps que tem tudo para agradar quem é ou não fã do gênero, irá
proporcionar ao gamer uma experência satisfatória.

reviewText:
From personal experience, I highly recommend Metro 2033 , and discurage the choise of buying metro 2033 Redux, the ambience is right, the steath system require some thinking, timing, as well as the ''moral'' aspect of the game is a thing that adds to the gameplay experience, you can chose to go in hot gun blazing or chose to silently assasinate as few enemies as possible and get pass thru them without notice, ''spoiler alert'' the stealth is very old fasion , no moving of bodies, and psst, dont take out lights if you can avoid doing so. The graphic and lighting may not be as advanced as in Redux version, but honestly the Redux version's lighting is just too saturated, and some of the inanimate objects, corpses, and other structure parts just randomly glows ?, uhm redux,,,,. if you want to play Metro 2033, play this version of the game.

Weapons: As mentioned above, there's choises you can make, that will have an impact to what may happen in the ending of the game'' ops that was a spoiler,'' anyways there's not much to say about the weapons beside there's arms dealers that in diferent levels of the game will offer to sell you differnte weapons some that may suit a stealthy play style some that will suit a more head on fire fighting type of play style, but the thing I actually wanted to bring in here is, that there's little hidden stashes of weapon, ammo and supplies around the map, don't rush thru the game just to finish . you'll miss out on the good stuff :). oh by the way . Volt Driver, dont leave that behind, highly recommend you keep that weapon once you get one, the shots from it is almost instant kill to all human enemy, and often instant kill for a lot of the mutant enemies as well.

Ammo: If you use the Smg or Assault riffles in the game as your main weapon, then you may want to make each bullet count or buy the low quality cartrages, ''millitary grade'' ammo can be hard to find when you need them the most, so make each shoot count !, Highly recommend shooting calmly with revolver instead of AR or SMG, or just keep your Volt Driver and use that as main weapon. :)

Other Supplies like Med kits / Health Kit, Granades, Throwing knives, Filters etc.
often located around the map near corpses of unfortunate others who got killed, but watch out for little arrows painted all over the place, and tripwire traps, those can be indication to hidden stashes of ammo, filters, med kits and more.

reviewText: I don't see why not many people have this game. It's a great FPS that takes place in underground Moscow, Russia due to an apocalypse. It's more of a Sci-Fi -ish Horror-ish shooter. You play as Artyom, a person who was raised in the underground and after a dear friend's disappearance, a delivery of a message depends on mankind. You meet people on the way who help you get through and they each have a unique character. There are two endings I heard, so be sure to get both of them! A great game to have and worth the buy!

reviewText: An immersive atmosphere, breathtaking visuals and unique features is what describes Metro 2033. Still holds the title for one of my favorite FPS to this day. It has its flaws like the Stealth sections. These can be difficult because of the AI. You're spotted for a milisecond and everyone instantly knows where you are, even in the dark enemies easily hit you. Overlooking these problems it's a really fun 4-5 hour experience which will surely get you hyped for the sequel Last Light.\nSave your Military Grade Ammo, pick up your Journal, your Revolver and your gas mask, now you're ready for this adventure through Moscow's Metro and its deserted surface!

reviewText:
Wow. Just wow. One of the best games I've ever played. This game is a must play for anyone who loves great games. In this game you play as Artyom where in a young age he is forced to seek help for his home after the nuclear fallout killed almost everyone except the people hiding in the Metros. The adventures and different creatures in this game are amazingly creative and there are different ways to counter them, also you can survive different situations on how you like and how you would do in real life (games forces you to survive the way it wants on few sitatuations).  This game also shows on how different ideologies still seperate humans on the toughest times.

PROS : No need for pros go try this game its amazing
CONS: DICKMOLES aka the moles which appear in a mission.. so annoying ( thanks to a friend for the name suggestion)

reviewText:
Experience of a lifetime

What can I say. I've been waiting for this game for a really long time. Luckily my rig allows me to play Dx10 on either High or Very High Settings. I was switching in between both since FPS falls in certain maps

This is truly an experience of a lifetime. As I was playing, I frequently noticed that my jaw was open - much like those brain dead 14-year old zombie kids playing Modern warfare and such all day long.

I haven't read the book, but definitely should now.

Im extremely happy that I can actually play this game in the original, in Russian language, since I speak it. And I recomment it to anyone wanting to experience the game in its purest form, of course the English subtitles can be enabled.

reviewText: Метро 2033 - красиво и тщательно сделанный линейный шутер. В игре использован вид на мир с точки зрения главного персонажа по имени Артём. Сюжет игры разворачивается в постапокалиптической Москве, преимущественно в московском метро. Локации в игре отражают мрачную атмосферу реальных туннелей метро. Сюжет представляет собой один большой флэшбек: действие начинается с финальной битвы, затем прерывается и переносится на неделю назад. Моя оценка 9/10.

reviewText: ARTYOM
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Every so often a game will come completely out of nowhere. It slides in right under the radar and manages to take you totally by surprise. These games are often made by new or up and coming development studios that most people really don't pay enough attention to and yet they manage to make games like Darksiders. The most recent game sleeper hit is definitely Metro 2033, a game that initially looked like a cheesy little b-horror movie inspired first person shooter but turned out to be a fair bit more than that.
Earth was destroyed years ago in a war of some sort that has left the world (or at least Russia) a radioactive mess. Those Russians who survived the war have abandoned the surface entirely due to this, choosing to instead make their home in the subway system that ran underneath their homeland. Due to this the surface has become infested with a new form of life; various mutants who have evolved to survive on the radioactive surface, flying through the skies or even harassing the humans underground. Stepping into this mess is our hero, Artyom, and through his ill-fated promise the player will be thrust into this strange new world.
On its surface Metro 2033 is a fairly typical example of the FPS genre with the notable exception that it's very story driven. Some might think to compare it to Fallout 3 but these are two very different games. You won't be doing any levelling up or assigning skill points in Metro 2033. The extent of your ability to modify your character is limited to choosing different weapons or weapons with different attachments.
Considering the fact that the world has been blown to smithereens and weapons are built with whatever is at hand you will get most of your equipment from scavenging. The currency of the world is military-grade ammunition, well crafted ammo from before the war, and you will have to find these valuable cartridges. Most of these will be from dead bodies whether it's the frozen long dead or warm bodies of your own creation but others can be found lying around in various locations. With this currency you can either buy dirty bullets"
date: weaker and cheaper ammunition manufactured by residents of the Metro as well as various guns. At one point you can even buy a new suit of armour
recommended: increasing your defences or sneaking abilities. It's not so much character customization as weapon load-out management.\nAs you travel the lonely tunnels of the Metro
hoursPlayed: scavenging for bullets and equipment off of the dead bodies you will notice just how claustrophobic this game is. Much of your time is spent travelling the lonely tunnels with only the mutants for company. At best you may have a single companion to guide you along but even these moments are tense affairs fraught with mutant chases or sightings of ghostly images in the tunnels. Sometimes the things you think you see out of the corner of your headlamps light is more disconcerting than the enemy that's bearing down on you. Even when there are no actual threats in the dungeons you can still find yourself jumping at shadows.\nEscaping to the surface is no consolation whatsoever because of its own manner of oppression. Due to the radiation that is blighting the land you will need to wear your gas mask at all times while above ground. Even though you will have to wear it at times while underground in hazardous areas you must wear it at all times above ground and it wears on you. Listening to Artyom's gasping as his filters run low
voteText: scavenging desperately for more filters from dead bodies and frantically fending off enemies so they don't shatter your mask on you all add up to make some of the most tense moments in recent video game memory.\nMaking matters yet worse
helpfulPercent: the skies are ruled by foul beasts that will stalk you if you don't hide from them. This turns certain areas of the surface into cat and mouse games and you are
votesHelpful: unfortunately
votesTotal: the mouse. Paired up with the mutant attacks it means you will never feel safe on the surface. That's not even getting into what other things wait for you inside of some of the remaining buildings.\nBut the game doesn't try to coast on atmosphere alone; there is a solid game here. Considering that almost all of the guns are made of scavenged materials they're not exactly the most reliable things in the world. Accuracy tends to be a bit on the iffy side for much of the game - Although it will always land within your targeting reticule it's sometimes a bit hard to judge exactly where it will land.\nAll of this atmosphere wouldn't mean a thing if the rest of the experience didn't add up. Luckily
votesFunny: for a smaller Ukrainian video game outfit
commentsCount: the guys at 4A Games have done a stellar job.\nWhile the graphics aren't necessarily the greatest to ever grace us
column16: they are more than suitable to the job especially considering most of the game is in near darkness. It's surprising just how good everything looks even under a scrutinizing eye. The only thing that's a bit lackluster are the human animations which can be on the robotic at times but you won't really notice since most humans you see are enemies and you will have more on your mind at these times.\nThe sound is something of a mixed bag when it comes to the voice acting but never where building atmosphere is concerned. Much of the voice acting was done by local talent which means you're listening to people talking with heavy accents. These don't always sound very convincing when speaking English
column17: some of the inflections are off or the dialogue sounds like it's being read from a script. But where the atmosphere is concerned this always excels.\nMetro 2033 is an incredibly chilling game experience. Many of the sections in the game aren't very difficult to get through
column18: even on the hardest difficulty
column19: but they will have you jumping at shadows nonetheless. There's just a sense of overwhelming dread that follows much of this experience that it's almost tempting to qualify this as a survival horror game."

reviewText:
A fantastic adaptation of the book that doesn’t miss out too much and plays great for a fan. Difficulty settings are a little extreme, however this is more of a survival horror at times rather than a FPS. The developers have done an amazing job to combine the two genres and create immersive, half-life 2 like environments  throughout the game that keep you on the edge of your seat and wanting to know more.

If you haven’t played this game I recommend it completely as a game enthusiast and a fan of the novel. The price definitely validates the story content plus the scares and triumphs you will endure during the campaign.

Check out last-light if you liked it! It’s every bit as good and better!

reviewText:
Video playthrough.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fav9bnsKNZE

Just a bit of backstory about Artyom for those of you that don't want to read the novel.
Artyom's station grows mushrooms which they then grind up into a powder to use for tea. His station makes the best mushroom tea which allows his station to survive. That's his job, to grind mushrooms into powder. He then catches a ride to the next station to deliver the mushroom tea powder along with other things. (That's how his journey starts off. The game doesn't go into any detail.)

Buy the book, it's so much better than the game.

The game is alright, kind of just average though. It doesn't seem so much based on the book as it is loosely following the story of the book.

A lot of content from the book is missing and it makes this game feel really short.
The book actually made it seem like a whole week to get to the tower but this game makes it seem like a few hours. Point is you'll need to read the book to know what's going on.
One of the benefits of this game is that you can see what the creatures actually look like.

The game is also really rough around the edges. Few bugs and glitches. It's as buggy as it is gritty.
Polis if you're unaware is the capital of the Metro and in the book it's described as this massive place with shops, a bustling market, loads of tents and lights so bright that outsiders have to wear sunglasses. In the game it's a square room and then you're just brushed away to somewhere else.

reviewText: Metro 2033 is a Post Apocalyptic Shooter in the style of Fallout just without the Rpg Stuff But will you want to play ths or just go to Fallout. In Metro 2033 you play as Artyom. He and the most population of Russia are living in the metro because all of theyre homes are destroyed by a post apocalyptic event. People Suffer mutations and turn into monsters. But among the monster theres a race called the dark ones. Artyom thinks of them as a threat so he ventures beyond the metro station where he grew up to warn people of the threat that are the dark ones. So how is Metro 2033 ? Its one of the best games on steam as of now. It plays like a normal shooter but there are elements that make it original. You have to conserve youre ammo because its gonna you will hav a limited amount of it. Youre inventory runs of a portable battery which you have to pump to keep youre equipment alive. You also have a gas mask because the outside air is now poison so you need to keep a mask with you at all times. Now the game looks amazing and if you have a titan PC its one of the best looking games Period. The game is quite fun but there are a few problems that haunt it. The game Gets quite tough near the end of it and it might throw some people off. The game also is quite confusing to navigate because even though its linear its also quite open for you to explore. There are alot of Bugs to this game as well so beware. Overall Metro 2033 is a game you need to own and play because its amazing. I give Metro 2033 a 9/10

reviewText: This game is difficult, but fun!  The dangerous environments, as well as having to fight the enemies in near darkness at times, just adds to the difficulty.  But the game certainly keeps you on your toes!  I'm still learning the bullet exchange system (bullets are used as currency in the game).  My only complaints are that there isn't a real obvious health meter" so rationing the first aid kits can be a challenge; it's pretty obvious when your character gets injured...but the extent of the injuries isn't always immediately obvious. In my 29 Hours of playtime, I have played through the game twice on two difficulties, and it never gets old. It is insanely addicting to me. The struggle for ammo is real, and adds tension to the air by the second. Best last resort is your knife, I had to do this in the intro with Hunter because they only gave you like 10 or so bullets for your Revolver on Ranger Easy. (This was the second playthrough, mind you.) However, I've never broken a mask, so I can't tell you what that's like. I'm sure its terrifying.

If your a fan of post-apocalyptic games, this one is definitely for you. The main currency of the game are old Military-Grade rounds, for God's sake. The patchwork of the weapons early on sell it even more. I swear, the Double-Barrel is made of tin cans.

I'm looking forward to playing Metro: Last Light for this Christmas. Oh, and if you are planning to get this game, I highly recommend getting the Redux Edition. All sorts of new goodies that the original doesn't have.

A first person shooter, with an element of horror and a well written story which keeps you interested till the end. This is a world that is heaving with apocalyptic detail, but also submerged in its own gaseous horrors. Both on the surface, and in certain areas of the Metro, you'll require a gas mask, which uses filters like a gun uses ammunition. The first time you die because of exposure to gases, you begin to realise that this is a shooter that is as much about survival as about the story, or the combat.

If the blunt harshness of STALKER isn't your cup of tea, but you like the setting, give Metro a whirl. It is a superb execution of a linear story-driven shooter with very satisftying gunplay and replayability. The only major flaw" is a lack of any multiplayer component."

I feel disappointed now, not that the game was bad, just that it's over, but I was happy at the same time. I love how the story just kept going for a long period of time, how the character was developing over time, and how the story was just coming together, making sense, like putting a puzzle together after each chapter was finished. You could do any strategy in this game you want, envisioning yourself into Artyom's frame of mind and control, from going to stealth, to bashing someone's skull into the wall, or making gunshots in the middle of a whole wave of enemies. In other words, I'm definitely buying the rest of this series soon and can't wait to see some more beauty being pieced together in the future.

A friend put it best when he said that 4A Games makes one of the best-looking corridor shooters ever. This game is linear... REALLY linear, but that's not bad. The game has a story to tell, and the linear structure is necessary for that. There's a lot of very, very interesting elements that the game touches on, things that I would definitely like to see revisited in a later game.

The game's not perfect, especially with regards to its stealth combat system, which will have you reloading saves over and over. This is especially true since every single silent weapon has a chance of being deflected by items worn by NPCs, stupid things like a throwing knife being deflected by a rubber gas mask. Yeah, right, that's fair.

Overall though this is a good game and worth a play. The story is good start to finish, and the whole thing is pretty entertaining. While the game isn't without frustrating moments, it's a satisfying play from beginning to end.

Like STALKER before it, the Post-Apocalypse era that has been cretaed here is immersive and very depressing, in a good way. It provides a very deep and rich atmosphere that I've rarely seen in a game. Metro's gameplay is very solid with great shooting and combat, although the AI isn't too impressive. The whole Bullets as currancy" idea works

reviewText: Singing Pipes sing the song of death.

Ranger mode: Brilliant immersion, and I can see why.

Frustrating, yes. Occasional buggy occurances, yes. A unique world with a unique story to tell? Very much yes.

I am very pleased with my purchase of this game, in which I took the story of Artyom into my own hands, and discovered a post-semiapocalyptic world ripe with color and detail. I was continually interested in the progression of my character, and the world around him. I didn't have much a say of Artyom, he wasn't a silent protagonist as much as he was a defined person - but I was interested in him, and I felt my actions helped shape him in slight.

Stealth is the required way to play the game, running and gunning with enough bullets to decimate a third world country will likely ruint he feeling of the game. Having said that, there are some truly frustrating parts to the game, and sometimes it gets rediculous. There are times when its very rewarding, and very immersive.

This is a good game if you like a challenge, and a very good buy.

So far this game is A+ it meshes story line with combat and cutscenes EXTREMELY well (I honestly had trouble telling if certain things were scripted). Provides a really immersive sense of realism, so far I can't stop playing. Well worth purchase.

The one downside is that it's poorly optimized.  I understand the remake addresses optimization, so go for the remake if prices are comparable.

very fun and educational

A basic linear shooter loaded with a cavalcade of innovative, unique and ingenious ideas that are all tragically hampered by mediocre execution. Ammo as currency! Seamless stealth/action gameplay! Animal enemies that can be intimidated rather than fought! 100% diegetic interface! It's a shame that there's special currency ammo, stealth is so unforgiving, the animal AI is so dodgy, and that the game is awkward and unpolished in general. Even the great atmosphere, story and setting are let down by total (often literally on-rails) linearity, crap voice acting and inadequate exploration of the non-hostile elements of the Metro.

Šmekerska igra. Napeta, teskobna i deprimirajuća, ekranizacija romana Dimitrija Glukovskog donosi jedno drugačije igračko iskustvo, koje se pre može okarakterisati kao epska akciona avantura nego kao klasičan FPS. Akcenat ovde nije na napucavanju sa hordama neprijatelja (iako i toga ima u solidnoj meri), već na konstantnom balansiranju između ograničenih resursa sa jedne strane i opšte neprijateljskog okruženja sa druge. Svaki tip oružja ima svoju vrstu municije, svako oružje može doći u nekoliko različitih varijacija, filteri za gas masku se brzo troše, a baterija za lampu mora konstantno da se puni uz pomoć ručnog dinama. Resursi su veoma ograničeni, zbog čega morate stalno da imate na umu spisak onoga što imate i onoga što vam nedostaje.

Ono u čemu Metro 2033 briljira jeste atmosfera, koja igru baca u sam vrh postapokaliptičnog podžanra.. Sama priča nije toliko dobro predstavljena (mada, pretpostavljam da su neke stvari dublje obrađene u literarnom predlošku) budući da je karakterizacija likova morala biti dublja, određeni momenti jasnije osvetljeni a i sam način pripovedanja nije najsrećnije rešen. Međutim, trud koji je uložen u detalje vidi se na svakom koraku: sitne životne drame stanovnika stanica metroa, deka koji svira neku prastaru melodiju svom unuku, fotografije starog sveta koje stalno podsećaju preživele na ono što su izgubili... Takve sitnice čine Metro univerzum sumorno živim, i ujedno neodoljivim za vas da se u njega uživite. Glasovna gluma je fantastična, a težak ruski akcenat i (ne)namerne greške u engleskom prevodu povećavaju dozu šarma kojim ova igra obiluje. Ponekad težak, sirov i robustan, Metro 2033, radi tačno ono što treba: u najboljem (post)sovjetskom maniru, prikazuje jedan izmišljeni mračni svet koji sutra može da postane realnost.

If you like Half-Life or in general linear games with strong narrative, action, and immersion, definitely pick this one up. It's got some light RPG and survival horror elements a la S.T.A.L.K.E.R., but the game is linear. This doesn't mean there's no replay value - I've played the game four times exploring levels for secrets stashes and discovering all kinds of small details. This game has a lot of care and detail put into it, and gamers who can appreciate the detail (along with its gameplay roots) will love it.

The game is not without its flaws, it has frequently unfair stealth and for a good chunk of the game you do not know what the hell with a lot of things unless you go to a wiki. Nonetheless, it is an amazing gaming experience. The game is surprisingly varied, no situation overstays its welcome. Sometimes you are going stealthy, others you go full blast mode and sometimes you do not see a shootable enemy for a good amount of time, but none of these happen for too long. Once you get the hang of it, the game turns a challenging, mostly fair and rewarding experience.  With very little to no handholding, this a refreshing experience as a game in general.

You can either Rambo through the game and have alot of problems(on higher diff's) or make it sneaky and spare all the Ammo for situations in which you can't avoid a fight (again Library im looking at you.)

All in all i'd give this game a 9/10 because i think they could somewhat work on the Stealth system because once enemys detect you you wont go back to undetected" at all. They always know you're there. But from what i heard they changed that in Metro Redux.

tl;dr: definitely worth a playthrough for the awesome mechanics and atmosphere, but probably no more than that because of frustrating stealth sections, fluctuating difficulty curve, and uninvolved story. Good game, especially if you got it for free.

What it does right: The atmosphere was amazing. I don't think I've ever played a post-apocalyptic game that made me love the world this much. The situation is dire and everything is rundown like you would expect after the near-extinction of humanity. All the little touches like the hand-made weapons and having to hold onto every bullet like it could mean your life set up a great setting that I really loved to run around in. Certain odd additions later on in the story didn't even take me out of the experience because they were implemented into the world so well. Even the mutants were a blast to try to fight through when every fight could mean a quick death.

The shooting mechanics weren't anything special, and neither was the weapon systems. The design of a lot of the guns were awesome, but I felt there was a missed opportunity to customize and create new weapons with the junk. Not enough of a thing to go in the bad, but it would've been cool.

While it wasn't perfect, a lot of little touches really made me like this game. Your npc companions could actually defend themselves, and when they couldn't, you never actually had to worry about babysitting them with a horde of enemies to worry about as well. Even down to the bounce of the laser pointer off of the glass. This game obviously had a lot of thought put into it, and the quality really shows in the final product. Even things like having to change a filter on a gas mask or recharging a flashlight were huge when it came to setting a mood for the game.

Also the visuals were very crisp and eye-catching. Definitely couldn't complain about graphics at any point in the game.

What it does wrong: Let's get the big one out of the way right at the start: stealth.

For all this game does right, I guess it had to get a few things wrong. I just wish what it did was so extremely frustrating. The stealth sections are so infuriating that most of the time I just shot my way through and it ended up being easier. I know I probably suck, but having an entire base know your exact location after one missed throwing knife attempt isn't a good game mechanic. A lot of the times I was even in cover and supposedly out of sight when all hell began to come down on me and kill me almost instantly. I may be wrong, but it seemed like these sections had the enemies do more damage than normal for near-instant deaths after being spotted. Either way, these sections almost made me want to drop the game altogether, and I dreaded when I saw a few throwing knives laid out for one that might be ahead.

The hit detection for the throwing knives was really odd as well. While at first I thought it might've just been armor or something making my knives bounce off, after three or four attempts to kill one guy and failing showed that this probably wasn't the case. This only happened two or three times in the entire game, but it was enough to ruin that attempt before it went anywhere.

As well as stealth sections being unnecessarily hard, there were a few others that felt like it was suddenly near-impossible to get through without lowering the difficulty.You'll know what sections I'm talking about when you get to them. But certain situations just seemed like it was just being downright unfair instead of hard.

Lastly, it's not a big one, but the story. A bit of a spoiler, but most of your companions either die or split off before you ever get a chance to get to know them. With the great world they built up, there was also a great chance to make some really awesome characters too. It gets better near the end, but the story becomes mostly a background thought to gameplay, and I felt like that detracted from the experience. Had they took the time to have some more character-centric moments and fleshed out some of your companions, the story would have been a lot more interesting, and every death would've hurt that much more when you start weighing it against your overall objective, but as it stands, I never really cared too much when people died around me when I never really got to know them in the first place.

While talking about the story, there were a lot of things that weren't fleshed out very well. I got the part about getting backup from polis to fight the dark ones, but missles? And there was apparently some massive city of dark ones on the surface? None of this was explained and it seems like it just happens cause the plot demands we go to new locations to fight something.  A lot more could've been done with Artyom's power to resist the dark ones, and who they were as well.

All in all, it was a fun game to play through, and a very interesting world to be in. I'll definitely check out it's sequel, but I don't know if I'll be giving this one another play through. Nothing much to go back for, and the thought of having to trudge through those stealth sections makes me groan. Would definitely recommend playing through this game at least once for the experience of it.

Metro 2033 is a Post Apocalyptic horror corridor shooter, and a pretty darn good one.  The story is quite good, if not fully explained; but I think leaving some mystery to it is for the best in this case.  Graphically it has a cosistently claustrophobic and grimy feel, with a decent variety of enemies which are enough of a threat to keep you on edge.  There is some variety in the weapons and they are pretty cool, but this could have been better as once you started a particular segment you rarely run into many weapons you can switch to, so consider your choices carefully.  Having to worry about keeping your flashlight charged, and conserving ammo and gas mask filters adds to the tension.   Took me about 10 hours to get through the story and I could see the pull to replaying it in ranger mode (sans hud and directional queues), but I'd avoid doing that before playing through the game first, as it doesn't always explain itself well ... or maybe it does and I just couldn't tell, because although the english voice acting is quite good, I found that it was basically inaudible at any distance from the NPCs.  ItSo maybe they were giving me a lot of queues that I just missed.  I probably wouldn't see replaying more than once though as it is quite linear.  I'd give it a recommend and an 8/10

This game had been in my library for some time. I started playing because I had the chance to try Last Light and thought it was great but I always try to play any series in order of release.
Perhaps the best thing about 2033 is its atmosphere and sense of style. You get to discover a whole living and breathing wrld in the tunnels of the metro. There's been a nuclear holocaust and the survivers have taken refuge underground. They have build new cities there and are trying to lead normal life but they are plagued by mutated monsters and the constant war between the different factions(Reds, Nazis, etc). Your journey will take you accross the whole network of the metro letting you see people in their daily environment. You can stop and just listen to their conversations and it's actually worth it but you don't have to do it if you don't want to. You'll also see the different sides of the conflict so you can make your own judgements. There's also the surface which you'll get to explore a bit but I wish there was more of it. It can be even more unnerving than the darkness of the tunnels. You have to wear a gas mask and watch your oxygen levels. While you're forced to listen to your character heavy breathing you are being attacked by mutated beasts.
Gameplaywise 2033 combines FPS with stealth elements. Unfortunately the stealth isn't that great. Sneaking by is not always an option and to kill silently you have only throwable knives and any silent weapons that you may have. These are not alway reliable since enemies later in the game have heavy armour and a headshot won't do and my knives just bounced off them sometimes. If your cover gets blown evry guard in the area knows your position and you'll likely get butchered. This led to some of the most frustrating moments of the game. When fighting enemy AI is ok but I caught them doing some weird stuff like taking cover on the wrong side of a wall and just begging to be shot. The sections where you fight mutants are exciting and challenging. This is not the kind of game which let's you play Rambo style. Ammo and supplies are scarce and you need to watch them closely.
Overall I like the weapons in the game - they realy look like they come from a post - apocalyptic world.I'm not a fan of the pneumatic ones which are powerful but require you to pump the manually as well as reloading them. They are unrliable when you are in a big fight surrounded by enemies. The game actually uses pre-war bullets as currency and you can either buy equipment with them or put them in your gun for a bigger punch.
In Metro 2033 you play as Artyom - a young man who has spent his live in his home station(town) and has no knowledge of the other parts of the metro. Now his people are being killed of by the Dark Ones. These are a new kind of mutants which seem to have some psychic powers. Artyom is somehow special and is able to establish contact with them. After even a highy trained soldier is disapers fighting the Dark Ones Aryom sets off for the city of the rangers(a neutral faction) to report the situation and ask for help. The game has strong sense of adventure. You'll meet several interesting characters along the way (Khan being my favourite) and you'll explore various  environments. There are two possible endings to the game but this may remain hidden for most players. I wouldn't have known myself if I haden't looked it up. If you intend to play the game only once look it up. Otherwise it's better not to splil it for yourself. Also the silent protagonist doesn't help storytelling much. Voice acting a bit of a hit and miss and some of the character models of the supporting charecters are difficult to distinguish from one another. Overall story is interesting, not the greatest but pretty good.
I should mention some of the main drawbacks for me. Like I said above stealth needs iprovement and AI could be a bit better. Also the controlls feel kind of weird (I play with a 360 controller). For instance melee and iron sights use one and the same button meaning you can't melee with some weapons and can't look through the sights with others. Also you have to cycle through weapons rather than having a seperate button for bringing up a selection menu. It's just not up to date with modern shooters (in terms of controls).
To sum it up I enjoyed the game and I recommend it to anyone who values atmosphere, story and a solid sinle player FPS experience. You ralely get so attention on the campaign especially in this genre. I've just started Last Light and it looks like it's not necessary to play the original to get in to it I suggest that you do.
This is actually my first review on Steam. I hope it helps someone :)

This is one of the best games I've ever played, atmospherically. If you've ever wondered what living in a post-apocalyptic world was like, this game captures it amazingly. Gameplay is intense and rewarding, if not uncompromising. You'll get the feeling you're fighting for your survival at every moment. Everything about this game is both grim and beautiful. You can feel the ragged hope in the metro stations, the relentless misery of the torn, blasted city above ground, and everything in between. From bandits to monsters, mutants to soldiers, and even ghosts and phenomena to the despair of life in the Metro, it will make you realize one thing: we can't relinquish the things that make us human.

Revisiting: Metro 2033

Original recommendation: A strange mix of Survival Horror and First Person Shooter, Metro 2033 is a well-scripted shooter in a highly atmospheric post apocalyptic world. The story is a little short, but full of shocking moments and fast-paced shooting. You're constantly encountering new factions, discovering interesting new locations, or being tasked to do something you haven't done before. Providing your system is capable, you'll be treated to a gorgeous experience which will make the game all the more immersive and fun to play.

The story: In 2033, Artyom, a 20-year-old survivor and one of the first-born in the metro, learns from an elite soldier, named Hunter that a group of mysterious creatures referred to as the Dark Ones are threatening his station in the Metro.
Having not read the source material, I can't say how faithfully it's adapted, however I can say its a great story with a surprising ending(s).

Presentation: Graphics are as good as they come: beautiful environments with a surprising amount of detail and fantastic animations. As for audio, the english voice acting is pretty poor, the guns don’t sound particularly powerful, but the monster noises will leave you quivering in fear.

Gameplay: For a first person shooter, there is actually surprisingly little shooting. There are some heavy action scenes and fights for survival against hordes of mutants, yet they are just one part of the game. The stealth aspect part is done fairly well - you can shoot or turn off most light sources and sneaking past everyone is sometimes a valid strategy. To top things off, there are also a couple of vehicle sections and the ability to upgrade your equipment by scavenging or buying better weapons.
In order to experience everything this game has to offer I recommend playing on ranger difficulty, with no crosshair and russian audio with your preferred subtitle option.

I'll start first by saying, before I played this, it had been a while since I found a game truly captivating. Dmitry Glukhovsky (The author of the book) has created a perfect atmosphere and environment, with points in which one truly values the existence of other people. With civilizations being far apart, one also feels that sense of insecurity whenever they are not within a civilization.

Despite the game being hugely linear, it makes up for it with immersion, atmosphere, story, detail and most, if not all aspects of the game. And, in saying it is a linear game, one is free to choose the how they'd like to take on the majority of battles, with a pleasing and sufficient array of weaponry to purchase and find.

It really is a flawless game for what it is, if it wasn't linear, it would come close to being my number 1 game. As it stands, it'll just have to settle for a favourite.

A really great game. I must say it is rather difficult though, I actually had to turn the difficulty down because I was getting wrecked left and right, defintiely not the type of game where you can go sprinting around a corner with a shotty blowing away everyone around you. Tactics, patience, if your not ready to plan out your appraoch before dashing into battle then prepare to die A LOT.

Metro 2033 is unique in its gameplay, but not so much in it's story. You're in post-apocalyptic Russia, too afraid of radiation to go above ground. So what do you do naturally? You stay in the intricate network of train stations and tunnels; the Russian Metro.

The graphics in this game are simply stunning. One of the most graphically advance games on the market, you will need some significant hardware to get a solid 60 frames per second. An AMD Radeon HD 7970 GHz edition or Nvidia GTX 680 should do the trick, if paired with a proper processor such as the i5 2500 or similiar Intel Quad-core. 4 gigabytes of ram is reccommended as well.

The gameplay is different from the likes of any other game I've played. The HUD is quite minimal, only showing what is necessary. That means no minimap, no crosshair (disabled by default, though it can be enabled.), and no health bar. The recoil of the weapons is quite realistic, though some of the guns are fictional so there is no real-life comparison.

I like this game, a lot. I would reccommend this if you are into games like Fallout, or even Dead Space. The genre is technically Survival Horror" -- though I've only actually jumped in situations where it's quiet and something pops out; nothing is horrible or terrifying

reviewText: I was lucky enough to get Metro free because of a limited offer on the Dev's facebook page, but it is certainly a game worth paying for. The atmosphere is great and the game is very immersive; there have been numerous occasions when I was genuinely pretty terrified. Weapon selection is a little limited but each gun is very indididual and fun to use; to be honest any more weapons would draw the focus away from the rest of the gameplay and make the game too loot orientated. Playing on normal difficulty provides sufficient challenge - enemy solider AI is not fantastic; combat is fun though and you certainly die very quickly so you don't feel like a bullet sponge and you really have to be on edge to survive. Well reccomended.
Don't play this game if you are offended by darkness.

In my 29 Hours of playtime, I have played through the game twice on two difficulties, and it never gets old. It is insanely addicting to me. The struggle for ammo is real, and adds tension to the air by the second. Best last resort is your knife, I had to do this in the intro with Hunter because they only gave you like 10 or so bullets for your Revolver on Ranger Easy. (This was the second playthrough, mind you.) However, I've never broken a mask, so I can't tell you what that's like. I'm sure its terrifying.

If your a fan of post-apocalyptic games, this one is definitely for you. The main currency of the game are old Military-Grade rounds, for God's sake. The patchwork of the weapons early on sell it even more. I swear, the Double-Barrel is made of tin cans.

I'm looking forward to playing Metro: Last Light for this Christmas. Oh, and if you are planning to get this game, I highly recommend getting the Redux Edition. All sorts of new goodies that the original doesn't have.

reviewText: awesome

Loved the game. Then I read the book! As I read I could hear the creepy, wet creaking of the tunnels I had crawled and run through while playing the game. The ideas presented in the book added depth to my understanding of the bleak world I had fought my way through and made me keen to experience the alternate endings.\nThese games present one of the most credible apocalyptic futures I have experienced. I felt immersed in the world that kept trying to kill me. Metro: Last Light was especially satisfying when I was able to address Artyom's anguish as he realised what he was destroying in the final moments of the novel.\nThe Metro games ask us to think about the way we approach the concept of us" and "them". Is it a default setting that causes humans to fear the "other"?"
Excellent game! Highly underrated, too

The idea of being forced to live in the metro of post apocalyptic Moscow was what got me hooked into the game. Once I started to play it the my experience just got better and better. I enjoyed the different weapons and gear your character could have. You also had to be careful with ammo, or else you'll find yourself in a tight situation. The game does a great job in making you have to work hard and think smart in surviving. reviewText: I was lucky enough to get Metro free because of a limited offer on the Dev's facebook page, but it is certainly a game worth paying for. The atmosphere is great and the game is very immersive; there have been numerous occasions when I was genuinely pretty terrified. Weapon selection is a little limited but each gun is very indididual and fun to use; to be honest any more weapons would draw the focus away from the rest of the gameplay and make the game too loot orientated. Playing on normal difficulty provides sufficient challenge - enemy solider AI is not fantastic; combat is fun though and you certainly die very quickly so you don't feel like a bullet sponge and you really have to be on edge to survive. Well reccomended.

I regularly suffer from insomnia and i needed to kill some brain cells so i could get to sleep. That proved to be a bad idea since i ended up staying awake all night playing the game. The atmosphere and sound design make such a strong and powerful impression with lots of clever writing that pulled me right in the moment i picked it up.

Metro 2033 is incredibly distinctive with the sound design. There's russian accents everywhere and lots and lots of little sounds that keep you on your toes as you play the game. A particularly memorable example of the sound design is the interactions between the various people you meet, especially the rangers later on, they all have really distinctive voices that sucks you in to the story so strongly that i swear i can still hear some of them.

Graphically this game shines as well. the various metro stations that you go to all feel like someones home and there's a fair amount of little side quests to do in said metros.

Being based of a book, this game has very solid and gripping writing with characters that are believeble and feel like they have genuine feelings for each other, such as the rangers that have little spats during the mission or Khan, the mystical man who genuinely makes you think about what you're doing.

Gameplay is also a strong FPS affair with a few interesting bits and pieces dropped in to keep it lively and interesting. An example is having two 'classes' of ammunition, one of which being Millitary Grade and the other the cheap Metro ones, Millitary rounds being used as a form of currency.

I had one fairly big issue to be honest, the FOV for what i'm used to is tiny and i believe it's only 75 Degrees. it isn't a detriment to the game but i found that increasing it makes the game a lot better to play.

In summary, Would i reccomend? Hell Yes! if you have put off playing this game, pick it up and play it!

Metro 2033 is a linear shooter at heart.  It then gives you a smattering of stealth, RPG, and other mechanics to fiddle with -- none of which it particularly excels at, but it does have an intriguing lean toward diagetic (visible-in-the-game-world) systems, for that you are there" touch.\n\nFor a game nominally about subway tunnels
recommended: if your computer is man enough for it.  The ruined urban areas above and below ground are beautiful and spooky instances of these kinds of spaces.\n\nFinally -- its eastern-European roots are showing in the overall mood of the game
hoursPlayed: and in a certain lack of nannying.  If you can roll with it
voteText: the freedom to fail helps maintain a workable illusion of agency.\n\nTogether these aspects are all about "pulling you in".  You won't keep playing Metro 2033 because of a gameplay skill challenge or a suspenseful story or collectibles or unlockables or levelling up. Its hook is simply a fascination for being in its world."

You listen to... something as it laughs, the sound travelling down the pipelines and into your ears. A screech, and you find yourself on the other side of the narrow tunnel.

Welcome to the Metro.

You are Artyom, a man on a journey beneath the noxious ruins of Moscow. Your mission: save your station from certain death.

But death is inevitable in such a world.

Sneak past monsters which may have once been human, or put them out of their misery, the choice is yours. With the help of a few good samaritans, you attempt to make your way to the central station in a world almost entirely underground to do what you think is right.

A noble cause. Or is there simply nothing else to believe...?
