reviewText:
NOTE:  There is a remastered version of this game on the Steam store called Metro 2033 Redux, this review is for the original, not that one.

_______________________________________________________________________________

Metro 2033 is a very well made game with a very memorable story to boot and graphics that really rocked for the time the game was released, and still look pretty damn good today.

You play as the Russian Artyom, in the year 2033, well after a nuclear winter has destroyed the surface world of Earth and the people of Russia have been forced underground to live in the metro tunnels due to how inhabitable the surface became.

This is all to mention nothing of the creatures that now lurk the Earth.  Moscow is now home to what it's people call Nosalises, Demons (♥♥♥♥♥es" if your name is Bourbon)
date: Librarians and more.  These are mutated
recommended: radiated and otherwise newly created/modified/evolved creatures that apparently aren't fond of humans.  The Nosalises are similar to large mutated mole-dogs with variants of many types ranging from flying to a rhino variant.  The Demons are large flying creatures
hoursPlayed: resembling a cross with a bat/gargoyle and possible tiger.  The Librarians are the real threat here; Large
votesHelpful: gorilla-looking beast that likes to snort around and bare their teeth.  The developers did an amazing job with bringing these creatures to life in this game
votesTotal: and really letting the player know that they aren't to be trifled with.  The general lack of ammo and medkits
votesFunny: coupled with the available frequency of encountering some of these creatures really makes you start to respect the game atmosphere and possibly cause to you be more cautious when navigating the game world to avoid certain death when you're low on ammo.\n\nThis game runs on ammunition.  Ammunition is the currency of the game world
commentsCount: as well as your primary source of self-defense (provided you have something to shoot the bullet out of).  The developers really did a great job of making the ammunition just hard enough to find on any difficulty that most players will be required to start thinking of how much they have
column16: how much they're using and what weapons would be best to use.  They also implemented some really cool weapons in the game
column17: such as the ghetto-rigged ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gun
column18: which is really only good at overheating itself and using up ammo
column19: but you'll likely encounter a time when it's all you got.\n\nThe characters in the game develop well and you can actually get to know some of them and develop a relationship/attachment to them.  They all have unique personalities
column20: even down to their names.  The game spends a lot of time trying to get you acquainted with the different characters
column21:
and does a great job of it.


The graphics and sound are very well done.  The graphics
column22: despite being an older game
column23: can still give newer hardware a bit of trouble due to the un-optimization of the game I believe.  The world design is great
column24: especially the moment you first step foot outside of the metro and see Moscow in the aftermath of the nuclear fallout with a Demon flying above crumbling gray buildings
column25: Nosalises running across things and your gas mask glaring and frosting up.\n\nThis game is one of my favorites and very underrated for what it is.  I certainly recommend this game."

reviewText: Great Game that is worth the purchase

Metro 2033 is a fine example of a cult classic. Metro 2033 may not do anything perticularly innovative it is a great example of how linear FPS's can provide a detailed and entertaining narrative experience.

Pros:
-Fantastic detail. Search around enough and you'll always find somewhere these people eat, sleep, trade and even poop.
-Strong narrative. A nice stroy with a few choices sprinkled along the way.
-Strong gunplay. You point and click, stuff dies - nice!
-Good stealth mechanics, stealth is almost always an option.
-Ranger modes. I highly recommend both ranger moders perticuarly ranger hardcore mode. They make combat leathal but    fair and it creates this organic shooter/stealth gameplay which most games cannot provide.
-Good graphics and audio.
-A great atmosphere. Both the towns, shootouts and horror elements all feel 'right'. They really nailed the atmosphere of the era and the book.

Cons:
-Linear. For those who hate corridors, stay away.
-Nothing that innovative. What there shines but it's nothing too new.
-Ranger Hardcore mode makes one part of the game close to impossible. You can change the difficultly on the fly and you'll probably have to for that one section (close to the end).

Overall great game - RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Metro 2033 was my first game I got on Steam. To be honest, I never knew what it is about - just heard a few things. Many years later now I thought that it's finally time to play it. That was a good choice but still, I wish I would decided to do it much earlier.

It was around beggining of autumn 2015. I'm glad I picked Metro 2033 to play during this season because for some reason it's the best time to play post-apocaliptic games, at least for me. While I wasn't so much curious about this game or the next one, once I started to play I get right into it. I felt how amazing Metro was. My first thought was it's kind of like Stalker games but sadly without open world. But I think it turned out to be good thing. I could say few things about graphics (it looks fantastic even many years after release), music, story or how great atmosphere this game have. To be honest, I would like only to say only something about Ranger mode. This is main reason why I enjoyed this game so much. Harder, but only because it's more realistic, and without any HUD you can enjoy Metro 2033 even more. It makes you think more serious about surviving in this cruel world, looking for other solutions that the obvious one. I wouldn't mind at all if it was replaced as normal game mode. This way more people who doesn't like to play a game few times could enjoy it too.

Too bad there is no option to buy this game anymore, since there is only Redux edition. Not sure if it's better but I heard only bad things about it, while compared to normal version of Metro 2033. Still, if you want to enjoy game with post-apocalyptic world, Metro 2033 (both this or Redux version) is great choice.

reviewText: I started playing computer games around 1996 and I have to say that I rarely found a game so haunting, atmospheric and challenging as Metro 2033. On first glance one might think it´s all in confined space underground
date: so its just one big shooting gallery". But you could not be more wrong. Depending on the level you play strategy and tactics are vital to survive. I rarely had the impression in other games that the game was literally trying to kill me (my character). You are confronted with all kinds of enemies plus a deadly
recommended: deadly outside world. I give Metro 2033 a (rare) 10/10."

reviewText:
So very, very immersive, you'll genuinely question if your loved ones are still alive. (Which, after finishing playing, I'd like to garuntee that they most probably are)

After reading the novel, I was skeptical about a game (the novel is less shoot-y, more think-y) but the immersion in the game is its chiefest quality by far. You could question the graphics, they are decent, even on lower qualities, but bear in mind that this wasn't a big studio budget game (even Last Light was 10% the budget of some of its competitors and look how well that did). The weapon animations and idle ones are, however, unique and (again) immersive.

The story isn't 100% faithful to the book I must add, but that's hardly a negative, it gives the same impression. That you (or your character, Artyom, unless you're so immersed that you've assumed his identity) are thrown from one event to the next, and by the time you've finished, you've realised that you've just completed one epic Odyssey across (and far below) Post-Apocalyptic Moscow.

PS. Look at my hours, that's genuine, it's rare you find such a good single player game.

This is one of the best games I've ever played, atmospherically. If you've ever wondered what living in a post-apocalyptic world was like, this game captures it amazingly. Gameplay is intense and rewarding, if not uncompromising. You'll get the feeling you're fighting for your survival at every moment. Everything about this game is both grim and beautiful. You can feel the ragged hope in the metro stations, the relentless misery of the torn, blasted city above ground, and everything in between. From bandits to monsters, mutants to soldiers, and even ghosts and phenomena to the despair of life in the Metro, it will make you realize one thing: we can't relinquish the things that make us human.
Great Game

Revisiting: Metro 2033

Original recommendation: A strange mix of Survival Horror and First Person Shooter, Metro 2033 is a well-scripted shooter in a highly atmospheric post apocalyptic world. The story is a little short, but full of shocking moments and fast-paced shooting. You're constantly encountering new factions, discovering interesting new locations, or being tasked to do something you haven't done before. Providing your system is capable, you'll be treated to a gorgeous experience which will make the game all the more immersive and fun to play.

The story: In 2033, Artyom, a 20-year-old survivor and one of the first-born in the metro, learns from an elite soldier, named Hunter that a group of mysterious creatures referred to as the Dark Ones are threatening his station in the Metro.
Having not read the source material, I can't say how faithfully it's adapted, however I can say its a great story with a surprising ending(s).

Presentation: Graphics are as good as they come: beautiful environments with a surprising amount of detail and fantastic animations. As for audio, the english voice acting is pretty poor, the guns don’t sound particularly powerful, but the monster noises will leave you quivering in fear.

Gameplay: For a first person shooter, there is actually surprisingly little shooting. There are some heavy action scenes and fights for survival against hordes of mutants, yet they are just one part of the game. The stealth aspect part is done fairly well - you can shoot or turn off most light sources and sneaking past everyone is sometimes a valid strategy. To top things off, there are also a couple of vehicle sections and the ability to upgrade your equipment by scavenging or buying better weapons.
In order to experience everything this game has to offer I recommend playing on ranger difficulty, with no crosshair and russian audio with your preferred subtitle option.

Graphics: 10
Sound: 7 (9 with russian audio)
Gameplay: 8
Story: 9
Multiplayer: N/A

Overall: 8.5/10

reviewText: Depressing, atmospheric, emotional, and frustrating. This game left me feeling unsure of what to think of it. It had put me in such a sad mood while playing, meaning it had a good story if it was able to make me feel something in the least, yet there were times where I wanted to just throw my laptop out the window from pure frustration from the game's bugs and unfixed issues. It's certainly playable, and for that matter, beatable, but there come times in the game where it feels as if neither of those things are true. I recieved my copy for free, so perhaps I shouldn't be harsh at all with it. But to others, it may come as a giant waste of time. I think if you buy it, you need to stay dedicated to it, and appreciate it for what it gives you. I also heard that Metro Last Light (the sequel) is better and I assume the Metro Redux that was made fixes those glitches, so you should probably just purchase the redux instead of the older version. If you're all about playing classic versions"
recommended: just be precautious of what problems await you."

This is the most atmospheric game I have ever played. I recommend this to all the stalkers.\nEverything in this game is brilliant. The graphics are awesome,the sound is very good, every single ♥♥♥♥in' detail is perfect.\n9,8/10 because the stealth was a little bit disappointing and because this game mad me ♥♥♥♥ my pants.

I hated this game when I first played it. I didn't like how dark it was all the time (I know that's silly because it's set in a metro but I still hated it), I thought it was needlessly complicated and so on. I don't think I made it past level 1 before uninstalling. About a year later I gave it another try and forced myself to play for at least a couple of hours and I realized that I absolutely loved it. It is one of the scariest games I have ever played and on ranger hardcore mode it is very very challenging - you have to think about each step you take carefully because you die QUICKLY and ammunition and other supplies are scarce. It is very immersive and the immense graphics add to this massively. The lighting and shadows too are amazing. When you have to go outside you need to make sure you carry filters for your gas mask and if you run out you're dead, unless you can run inside very quickly, which you won't be able to unless you're right at the end of the level. There isn't too much exploration to be found, but there is some and it is rewarded with precious ammunition and other supplies.\n\nFor balance I will mention a few things I don't like. Stealth is broken. Sometimes it works, other times if one single enemy is alerted to your presence then every single enemy on the level will know where you are forever. Also they sometimes see you even if you're hiding in total darkness, even if they don't have a flashlight or night vision equipment. Another thing that annoyed me was how good and bad ammunition looks so alike you often can't tell what you're firing. In this game clean" ammunition is currency
date: you buy stuff with it and sell stuff for it. It's like money. "Dirty" ammunition is ammunition that is made by metro inhabitants. It does less damage but you get more of it
recommended: so you want to use as much dirty ammunition as possible and keep your clean ammunition to buy supplies (except in emergencies where you have to load clean ammunition in to your gun because you're out of dirty ammo). The problem is that the levels are so dark you often accidentally fire all of your clean ammo without realizing it because they look pretty much the same. This isn't a problem if you play on easy mode because the HUD tells you what you're firing
hoursPlayed: but on hard or ranger modes you have no HUD at all.\n\nOverall though this is a fantastic game and MUCH better than the sequel."

reviewText: Best SP Game EVER

10/10
The comparisons between the Metro and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series are often, and rightly, made. Metro is very much the slick, story-channeled sibling of the more free-roaming S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. Both are brilliant, and I am unashamedly and irretrievably biased towards both. Metro 2033 shows just how open-world a channelled game can feel when it is honed with artistry and innovation at every turn. Story is always central to the Metro games. However, I never once felt I was being moved on too speedily, or claustrophobically led through the story.

The inventory system - or lack thereof - was an irritation at first. This did not last, however.  (Here I should mention that, as with Last Light, I only played the game on Ranger mode, which apparently has a more limited UI than the standard mode of the game). The weapons in 2033 have a wealth of character and personality, making an inventory UI all but unnecessary. The way ammo is handled, however, could be improved upon. Pre-war ammo can be used as currency as well as ammunition, and is only distinguished by a slightly brighter icon. Several times I found myself firing this currency inadvertently.

The characters are rich and real; at times they took and left the stage too speedily, but never so fast as to fail to make an impact. I ended the game with a clear memory of the characters as a distinct and tangible cast. The larger narrative too is one that manages to surprise and move the player.

With the graphics set to high, this game will challenge the most advanced gaming PCs. I found 2033 stressed my rig more than Last Light, in fact. The work is warranted - textures are deep and detailed. Even in dimly lit passages, lighting is applied with skill and balance.

What I liked about the game was the overall dark and sinister setting, the anomalies, the mutants, the story, the situations the game puts you in. It has really good fights in it as well as really atmospheric situations that are sometimes scary, sometimes just nice to look at. I played other games set in the post-apocalypse, and the world the developers created is a very good and intense one. Hard to think of something I don't like, really. If you are into post-apocalypse, get the game, get headphones and play.

Another awkward morality system led to a non-choice at the end of the game that didn't make sense. This game switches gears frequently, and this can lead to some supply problems if you aren't reading ahead or just lucky. Otherwise, the game has a lot of atmosphere, some workmanlike action, and a plot that would be excellent if it was not so silly. You might already own it as part of a bundle, and if not, consider buying it if you like the post-apocalypse or Russia.

reviewText: Best SP Game EVER

The idea of being forced to live in the metro of post apocalyptic Moscow was what got me hooked into the game. Once I started to play it the my experience just got better and better. I enjoyed the different weapons and gear your character could have. You also had to be careful with ammo, or else you'll find yourself in a tight situation. The game does a great job in making you have to work hard and think smart in surviving. I didn't really pay attention to graphics because it should be the story that counts, and the story was amazing. This game is perfect for anyone who enjoys a FPS with horror and adventure aspects. I hope that you have as much fun as I did when I played this game.
Great singleplayer fps with loads of atmosphere, well scripted and some good set-pieces. Only the odd difficulty spike mars this game.

reviewText: This game is a great post-apocalyptic adventure with a great story! A lot less buggier than Fallout.

Metro takes the themes and environments of Stalker and breeds it with the frenetic shooting of more common modern FPS games like CoD or Fear. Overall, it's weaker than Stalker, but what isn't? Still a good, fun game that I couldn't put down.

I totally lost myself in this game.

No doubt this is a unique first-person shooter game in recent years, probablely the best.Unlike mostly shooter game,there is no fierce battle, no exploding scenes, no grand symphonic backgroundmusic, no revenge, no conspiracy,no saving the world,no good or evil. There is only a man hiding in the underground playing his old guitar,there is only a man who keeps his oath, there is only a man struggle in those dark tunnnels just for safety of his home.This game showed us a big world.A world that nazi and red army still fight with each other while entire human are in very danger of extinction after the nuclear war.A world that mutant monsters have occupied the surface instead of sword and fire.

The story line is simple, but still absorbing,especially the journal part which makes me feel like artyom himself.Compare to other shooter games, this game has few battle part, but every single one is absolutely exciting,and that is why metro 2033 is good. They have thire own way to tell a story.Mostly, artyom is on his own, alone in the dark, worried about the filter on his gas mask, or try to find anything useful on dead bodies. Though there are some friends come to help artyom, nobody can finish the way in front of artyom. When I playing this game, the only thing I care about is how to survive, not just shoot everybody's head in front of me. Sometimes I have to run away from those monsters, because ammo is valuable and hard to find. The biggest puzzle in this game is the Drak One, I keep playing and playing just want to find the answer.Who is the Drak One? How can I stop him? The game is replayable, there are two different ending, and that depends what chioce you wuold make in the game.

Thanks to the great graphic, the world of 2033 is just like a real one. They did a fine work of texture and light. The dreadful monsters, the soldiers, the gloomy lights in tunnels, I have never seen such amazing things in other games. Everyone should paly this game, it is a kind of experience that you dont want to forget.

Metro: 2033 serves as a testament to the potential of an adaption of a novel into a form of interactive media, with a world similar to that of Stalker, and its own unique and intriguing story and background lore, this serves as a very outstanding and unique game, with everything being well thought-out and planned, even down to that of the currency. Although there are some glaring isssues in the game (due to it's age), the clunky stealth is upgraded dramatically in the sequel and remake. Always a solid pick-up, especially due to the frequency of when you can get it for free.

Metro 2033 is a game that I can easily recommend to any gamer that loves playing Fallout. It has a great story and Metro: Last Light is no different. These games are very fun and any Fallout fan should give them a try.

You play as one of the many survivors living in the Moscow underground metro system. After the nuclear war that have destroyed the surface of the planet, and made it almost impossible to live on top. Interesting story with never before explored underground metro environments and atmospheric ambiance.

Levels are mostly linear with some additional room to explore. Survivor towns are creatively designed and have a lived in" feel. Some areas require you to use gas masks in order to survive. Ammunition is literally in weight of gold
date: and every round means life or death.\n\nEnemy variation is small
recommended: from simple humans to monsters and mutants. Depending on your play style

I give Metro 2033 an 8.5/10.

I had a lot of fun playing this; nasty fights with crappy guns, nazis, mutants and a tight economy with the ammo. Gung-ho bravado and sneaking around are both nessessary and the use of iron sights for most bun fights is recommended. The weapons are unusually comfortable - I particularly liked the throwing knives for a quick and silent dispatch and grenades, carefully placed, were a great ice-breaker when things got too serious. The landscaping and atmosphere were beautiful to behold and the soviet technology was a laugh; pausing in the middle of a desperate  gun battle to pump a dynamo to charge your night-vision goggles was a hoot. Shades of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series and Fallout 3 with a tip of the hat to Doom 3, I heartily recommend a stay in the tunnels of Metro 2033 for anybody that likes a good adventure. The end gets a bit freaky but the setting and the situation sort of call for that anyway. Needs a good machine to run well...
